_**Spider-Man: Homecoming**_ is a 2017 American [superhero film](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superhero_film "Superhero film") based on the [Marvel Comics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Comics "Marvel Comics") character [Spider-Man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man "Spider-Man"), produced by [Columbia Pictures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Columbia_Pictures "Columbia Pictures"), [Marvel Studios](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Studios "Marvel Studios"), and [Pascal Pictures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pascal_Pictures "Pascal Pictures"), and distributed by [Sony Pictures Releasing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony_Pictures_Releasing "Sony Pictures Releasing"). It is the second [Spider-Man film](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man_in_film "Spider-Man in film")[reboot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reboot_(fiction) "Reboot (fiction)") and [the 16th film](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Marvel_Cinematic_Universe_films "List of Marvel Cinematic Universe films") in the [Marvel Cinematic Universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe "Marvel Cinematic Universe") (MCU). The film was directed by [Jon Watts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jon_Watts "Jon Watts") from a screenplay by the writing teams of [Jonathan Goldstein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonathan_Goldstein_(filmmaker) "Jonathan Goldstein (filmmaker)") and [John Francis Daley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Francis_Daley "John Francis Daley"), Watts and [Christopher Ford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_Ford_(screenwriter) "Christopher Ford (screenwriter)"), and [Chris McKenna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_McKenna_(writer) "Chris McKenna (writer)") and [Erik Sommers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erik_Sommers "Erik Sommers"). [Tom Holland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Holland "Tom Holland") stars as [Peter Parker / Spider-Man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Parker_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Peter Parker (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"), alongside [Michael Keaton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Keaton "Michael Keaton"), [Jon Favreau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jon_Favreau "Jon Favreau"), [Gwyneth Paltrow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gwyneth_Paltrow "Gwyneth Paltrow"), [Zendaya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zendaya "Zendaya"), [Donald Glover](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Glover "Donald Glover"), [Jacob Batalon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_Batalon "Jacob Batalon"), [Laura Harrier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laura_Harrier "Laura Harrier"), [Tony Revolori](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Revolori "Tony Revolori"), [Bokeem Woodbine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bokeem_Woodbine "Bokeem Woodbine"), [Tyne Daly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyne_Daly "Tyne Daly"), [Marisa Tomei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marisa_Tomei "Marisa Tomei"), and [Robert Downey Jr.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Downey_Jr. "Robert Downey Jr.") In the film, Parker tries to balance high school life with being Spider-Man while facing the [Vulture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adrian_Toomes_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Adrian Toomes (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") (Keaton).

In February 2015, Marvel Studios and Sony reached a deal to share the film rights for Spider-Man, integrating the character into the established MCU. The following June, Holland was cast as the title character, and Watts was hired to direct. This was followed shortly by the hiring of Daley and Goldstein. In April 2016, the film's title was revealed, along with additional cast, including Downey in his MCU role of [Tony Stark / Iron Man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Stark_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Tony Stark (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"). Principal photography began in June 2016 at [Pinewood Atlanta Studios](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinewood_Atlanta_Studios "Pinewood Atlanta Studios") in [Fayette County, Georgia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fayette_County,_Georgia "Fayette County, Georgia"), and continued in Atlanta, Los Angeles, and New York City. The other screenwriters were revealed during filming, which concluded in Berlin in October 2016. The production team made efforts to differentiate the film from previous Spider-Man films.

_Spider-Man: Homecoming_ premiered in [Hollywood, Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hollywood,_Los_Angeles "Hollywood, Los Angeles"), on June 28, 2017, and was released in the United States on July 7, as part of [Phase Three](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe:_Phase_Three "Marvel Cinematic Universe: Phase Three") of the MCU. _Homecoming_ grossed over $880 million worldwide, becoming the second-most-successful Spider-Man film and the [sixth-highest-grossing film of 2017](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_in_film#Highest-grossing_films "2017 in film"). It received praise for the light tone, its focus on Parker's high school life, and the performances, particularly of Holland and Keaton. Two sequels have been released: _[Spider-Man: Far From Home](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:\_Far\_From\_Home "Spider-Man: Far From Home")_ (2019) and _[Spider-Man: No Way Home](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:\_No\_Way\_Home "Spider-Man: No Way Home")_ (2021). A new trilogy of live-action films from Sony and Marvel Studios is in development.

Following the [Battle of New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_New_York_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Battle of New York (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") in 2012,[[a]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-5)[Adrian Toomes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adrian_Toomes_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Adrian Toomes (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") and his salvage company are contracted to clean up the city, but their operation is taken over by the [Department of Damage Control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damage_Control_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Damage Control (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") (DODC), a partnership between [Tony Stark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Stark_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Tony Stark (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") and the [U.S. government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal government of the United States"). Enraged at being driven out of business, Toomes persuades his employees to keep the [Chitauri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chitauri_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Chitauri (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") technology they have already scavenged and use it to create and sell advanced weapons, including a flying [Vulture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vulture_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Vulture (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") suit Toomes uses to steal Chitauri power cells.

Eight years later,[[b]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-8) after being drafted into the [Avengers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avengers_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Avengers (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") by Stark to help with an internal dispute in [Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germany "Germany"),[[c]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-11)[Peter Parker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Parker_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Peter Parker (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") resumes his studies at the [Midtown School of Science and Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midtown_School_of_Science_and_Technology "Midtown School of Science and Technology") when Stark tells him he is not yet ready to become a full-time Avenger. Parker quits his school's [academic decathlon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academic_decathlon "Academic decathlon") team to spend more time focusing on his crime-fighting activities as Spider-Man. His best friend, [Ned](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ned_Leeds_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Ned Leeds (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"), eventually discovers his secret identity.

Parker comes across Toomes's associates [Jackson Brice / Shocker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackson_Brice_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Jackson Brice (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") and [Herman Schultz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herman_Schultz_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Herman Schultz (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") selling weapons to local criminal [Aaron Davis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aaron_Davis_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Aaron Davis (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"). Parker saves Davis before being caught by Toomes in the Vulture suit and dropped in a lake, nearly drowning after becoming tangled in a parachute built into his suit. He is rescued by Stark, who is monitoring the Spider-Man suit he gave Parker and warns him against further involvement with the criminals. Toomes accidentally kills Brice with one of their weapons and Schultz becomes the new Shocker.

Parker and Ned study a weapon Brice left behind, removing its power core. When a tracking device on Schultz leads to [Maryland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maryland "Maryland"), Parker rejoins the decathlon team and accompanies them to [Washington, D.C.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.") for their national tournament. Ned and Parker disable the tracker Stark implanted in the Spider-Man suit, and unlock its advanced features. Parker tries to stop Toomes from stealing weapons from a DODC truck but is trapped inside, causing him to miss the decathlon tournament. When he discovers that the power core is an unstable Chitauri grenade, he races to the [Washington Monument](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Monument "Washington Monument"), where the core is activated and explodes, trapping Ned and their friends in an elevator. Parker saves them, including his classmate and crush [Liz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liz_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Liz (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"). Days later, in [New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), aboard the [Staten Island Ferry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Staten_Island_Ferry "Staten Island Ferry"), Parker captures Toomes's new buyer [Mac Gargan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mac_Gargan_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Mac Gargan (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") but Toomes escapes and a malfunctioning weapon tears the ferry in half. Stark helps Parker save the passengers, but confiscates his suit as punishment for his recklessness.

Parker returns to his high school life and asks Liz to go to the [homecoming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homecoming "Homecoming") dance with him. On the night of the dance, he discovers that Toomes is Liz's father. Deducing Parker's secret identity, Toomes threatens him. Parker realizes Toomes is planning to hijack a DODC plane transporting weapons from [Avengers Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avengers_Tower_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Avengers Tower (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") to the team's [new headquarters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avengers_Compound_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Avengers Compound (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") in Upstate New York. He leaves the dance and dons his old homemade Spider-Man suit. Though he is ambushed outside by Schultz, he defeats him with Ned's help. He races to Toomes's lair, where Toomes attacks Parker, destroying the building's support columns, and leaves Parker to die, trapped in the rubble of the collapsed building. Gaining the motivation from his inner strength, Parker escapes and intercepts the plane, steering it to crash on the beach at [Coney Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coney_Island "Coney Island"). He and Toomes continue fighting, ending with Parker saving Toomes's life after the damaged Vulture suit explodes. Parker leaves Toomes for the police along with the plane's cargo. After her father's arrest, Liz moves away. Parker declines an invitation from Stark to join the Avengers full time, and Stark proposes to [Pepper Potts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pepper_Potts_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Pepper Potts (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"). Stark also returns the Spider-Man suit to Parker, who puts it on just as his aunt [May](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/May_Parker_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "May Parker (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") walks in.

In a [mid-credits scene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mid-credits_scene "Mid-credits scene"), an incarcerated Gargan approaches Toomes in prison, saying he has heard that the latter knows Spider-Man's real identity, though Toomes denies this.

[![Image 2](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Spider-Man_Homecoming_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg/250px-Spider-Man_Homecoming_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Spider-Man_Homecoming_by_Gage_Skidmore.jpg)

(L–R) [Tom Holland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Holland "Tom Holland"), [Laura Harrier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laura_Harrier "Laura Harrier"), [Tony Revolori](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Revolori "Tony Revolori"), [Jacob Batalon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_Batalon "Jacob Batalon"), [Zendaya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zendaya "Zendaya"), and director [Jon Watts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jon_Watts "Jon Watts") promoting _Spider-Man: Homecoming_ at the 2016 [San Diego Comic-Con](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Diego_Comic-Con "San Diego Comic-Con")

*   [Tom Holland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Holland "Tom Holland") as [Peter Parker / Spider-Man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Parker_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Peter Parker (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"):

A 15-year-old who gained spider-like abilities after being bitten by a radioactive spider.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-SpideyAge-12) Producers [Kevin Feige](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Feige "Kevin Feige") and [Amy Pascal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amy_Pascal "Amy Pascal") were impressed by Holland's performances in _[The Impossible](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Impossible\_(2012\_film) "The Impossible (2012 film)")_ (2012), _[Wolf Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wolf\_Hall\_(TV\_series) "Wolf Hall (TV series)")_ (2015), and _[In the Heart of the Sea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In\_the\_Heart\_of\_the\_Sea\_(film) "In the Heart of the Sea (film)")_ (2015).[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-HollandWatts-13) Holland took inspiration from previous Spider-Man actors [Tobey Maguire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tobey_Maguire "Tobey Maguire") and [Andrew Garfield](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Garfield "Andrew Garfield") but also hoped to deliver something "new and exciting" with his take on the character,[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-HollandHeyUGuys-14) the first to focus on Parker as "dealing with everyday problems that a 15-year-old deals with as well as trying to save the city".[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-HollandJuly2016-15) Holland attended [the Bronx High School of Science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Bronx_High_School_of_Science "The Bronx High School of Science") in [the Bronx](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Bronx "The Bronx") for a few days to prepare for the role,[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-HollandVarietyMar2017-16) where other students did not believe he was cast as Spider-Man. Holland felt this would carry over well to the film, where other characters do not suspect Parker of being Spider-Man.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-HollandHSVisit-17) It took 25 to 45 minutes for Holland to get into costume, depending on if he had to wear a stunt harness underneath the suit.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-HollandVarietyMar2017-16) Holland initially signed for six MCU films, including three Spider-Man films.[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-HollandContract-18)
*   [Michael Keaton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Keaton "Michael Keaton") as [Adrian Toomes / Vulture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adrian_Toomes_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Adrian Toomes (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"):

A salvager-turned-arms-trafficker after his company is forced out of business. He uses a suit with mechanical wings forged from [Chitauri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chitauri "Chitauri") technology.[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-USATodayMar2017-19) Toomes is revealed to be the father of [Liz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liz_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Liz (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"), Parker's love interest.[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-DaleyGoldsteinTHR2-20) Director [Jon Watts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jon_Watts "Jon Watts") wanted him to be a "regular guy", closer to [John C. Reilly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_C._Reilly "John C. Reilly")'s [Nova Corpsman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nova_Corps_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Nova Corps (Marvel Cinematic Universe)")[Rhomann Dey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhomann_Dey_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Rhomann Dey (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") from _[Guardians of the Galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guardians\_of\_the\_Galaxy\_(film) "Guardians of the Galaxy (film)")_ (2014) than other MCU villains like [Thanos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thanos_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Thanos (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") and [Ultron](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultron_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Ultron (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"), to go with Spider-Man as a "regular kid who becomes a superhero".[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-USATodayMar2017-19)[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-USATodayDec2016-21) This helped avoid Toomes drawing the attention of the [Avengers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avengers_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Avengers (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"), and provided someone that Parker would be able to defeat while still learning to use his abilities.[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-GoldsteinDaleyCS-22) Keaton said Toomes was not completely villainous, as "there's parts of him that you go, 'You know what? I might see his point.'"[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-KeatonVarietyJan2017-23) Co-producer [Eric Hauserman Carroll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eric_Hauserman_Carroll "Eric Hauserman Carroll") likened Toomes to "the dark [Tony Stark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Stark_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Tony Stark (Marvel Cinematic Universe)")",[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-USATodayMar2017-19) a "businessman with a family. He wants to look out for his kids ... He doesn't have these big delusions of grandeur where he wants to take over the world, or replace the government, or even defeat the Avengers or anything. He just wants his shot at the good life."[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-/FilmSetVisitPg2-24) Keaton was not hesitant to portray another comic book character after playing [Batman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batman "Batman") in [Tim Burton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Burton "Tim Burton")'s [1989 film](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batman_(1989_film) "Batman (1989 film)") and its [1992 sequel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batman_Returns "Batman Returns").[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-KeatonVarietyJan2017-23)
*   [Jon Favreau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jon_Favreau "Jon Favreau") as [Happy Hogan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Happy_Hogan_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Happy Hogan (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"):

The former head of security for [Stark Industries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stark_Industries_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Stark Industries (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") and Tony Stark's driver and bodyguard.[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Favreau-25) Hogan is "looking after" Parker in the film, with Favreau saying that Parker "needs someone to help him out".[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FavreauDec2016-26) Favreau previously portrayed Hogan in the _Iron Man_ films, having also directed the first two of those, and described returning as just an actor as fun, allowing him "to maintain the relationship with the MCU ... Especially when the filmmakers are taking care of you, and taking care of the characters and the story."[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FavreauSep2016-27)
*   [Gwyneth Paltrow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gwyneth_Paltrow "Gwyneth Paltrow") as [Pepper Potts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pepper_Potts_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Pepper Potts (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"): Tony Stark's fiancée and the CEO of Stark Industries.[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Paltrow-28)
*   [Zendaya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zendaya "Zendaya") as [Michelle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MJ_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "MJ (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"):

One of Parker's classmates, also known as "MJ".[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-EWCastnames-29)[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-ZendayaRole-30) Zendaya, calling her awkward but intellectual, said that "she just feels like she doesn't need to talk to people" because of her intelligence.[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-ZendayaTHRNov2016-31) She added that it was "refreshing" that Michelle was weird and different, feeling that "a lot of young people—especially young women—can relate to that."[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-ZendayaDigitalSpy-32) Watts likened the character to [Ally Sheedy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ally_Sheedy "Ally Sheedy")'s Allison Reynolds from _[The Breakfast Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Breakfast\_Club "The Breakfast Club")_ (1985) or [Linda Cardellini](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linda_Cardellini "Linda Cardellini")'s Lindsay Weir from _[Freaks and Geeks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freaks\_and\_Geeks "Freaks and Geeks")_ (1999–2000).[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-/FilmSetVisitPg2-24) The character is not a direct adaptation of [Mary Jane Watson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_Jane_Watson "Mary Jane Watson"), but was given the initials "MJ" to "remind you of that dynamic",[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FeigeDenOfGeek-33) with the writers "plant[ing] the seeds in this movie" for comparisons to Watson, but also making her "wholly different".[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-DaleyMichelle-34) Feige added that Michelle is "not obsessed with" Parker like Watson is at times in the comics, "she's just observant".[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FeigeDenOfGeek-33) Her full name, Michelle Jones-Watson, was revealed in _[Spider-Man: No Way Home](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:\_No\_Way\_Home "Spider-Man: No Way Home")_ (2021).[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FullNames-35)
*   [Donald Glover](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Glover "Donald Glover") as [Aaron Davis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aaron_Davis_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Aaron Davis (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"):

A criminal looking to purchase weapons from Toomes.[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Glover-36)[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-GloverRole-37) Davis is the uncle of [Miles Morales](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miles_Morales "Miles Morales"), an inheritor of the Spider-Man mantle, in the comics. Glover voiced Morales in the _[Ultimate Spider-Man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultimate\_Spider-Man\_(TV\_series) "Ultimate Spider-Man (TV series)")_ television series, and campaigned to portray Spider-Man in a film in 2010. Watts was aware of the campaign, and as soon as he was hired he asked Feige about casting Glover. The role was designed as "a surprise treat for fans", with Davis mentioning his nephew to set up Morales potentially appearing in a future MCU film.[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-GloverRole-37) Watts insisted Glover accept the part, assuring him that if he declined the offer, he would have scrapped Davis from the film.[[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Glover/Film-38)
*   [Jacob Batalon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_Batalon "Jacob Batalon") as [Ned](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ned_Leeds_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Ned Leeds (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"):

Parker's best friend,[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-EWCastnames-29)[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-SDCC2016-39)[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-IGNNedLeeds-40) who is a "complete gamer".[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-LeedsGamer-41) Batalon described him as "the quintessential best guy, the best man, the number two guy, the guy in the chair" for Parker.[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-BatalonCBR-42) Marvel used [Ned Leeds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ned_Leeds "Ned Leeds") as a basis for the character, who does not have a last name in the script or film, but essentially created their own character with him. Carroll said that Ned and other characters in the film are composites of several of their favorites from Spider-Man comics,[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-IGNNedLeeds-40) notably [Ganke Lee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ganke_Lee "Ganke Lee"), who is [Miles Morales](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miles_Morales "Miles Morales")' best friend in _[Ultimate Comics: Spider-Man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultimate\_Comics:\_Spider-Man "Ultimate Comics: Spider-Man")_.[[40]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-NedGanke-43) He is given the last name "Leeds" in the sequel _[Spider-Man: Far From Home](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:\_Far\_From\_Home "Spider-Man: Far From Home")_ (2019),[[41]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-LeedsLastName-44) which was confirmed in _No Way Home_.[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FullNames-35)
*   [Laura Harrier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laura_Harrier "Laura Harrier") as [Liz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liz_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Liz (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"): A senior, Parker's love interest, and Toomes's daughter,[[42]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Harrier2-45)[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-USATodaySDCC2016-46) with a ["type-A" personality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_A_and_Type_B_personality_theory#Type_A "Type A and Type B personality theory").[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-/FilmSetVisitPg2-24)
*   [Tony Revolori](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Revolori "Tony Revolori") as [Flash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flash_Thompson_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Flash Thompson (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"):

Parker's rival and classmate.[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-USATodaySDCC2016-46)[[44]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Revolori-47) It was noted that the character is generally depicted as a white bully in the comics; the Guatemalan American actor received death threats upon his casting.[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-USATodaySDCC2016-46)[[45]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-RevoloriCBR-48) Revolori worked hard "to do him justice", as he is an important character to the fans.[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-USATodaySDCC2016-46) Rather than being a physically imposing jock, Flash Thompson was reimagined as "a rich, smug kid" to reflect modern views of bullying,[[46]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Revolori2-49) by crafting him more into a social media bully and rival for Parker opposed to a jock;[[45]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-RevoloriCBR-48) this depiction was largely informed by Holland's visit to the Bronx High School of Science.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-HollandVarietyMar2017-16) Revolori said that Flash has to work hard to match Parker's intelligence, which is "one of the reasons he doesn't like Peter. Everyone else seems to like Peter, so he's like, why don't they like me like they like him?" Revolori gained 60 lb (27 kg) for the role.[[45]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-RevoloriCBR-48)
*   [Bokeem Woodbine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bokeem_Woodbine "Bokeem Woodbine") as [Herman Schultz / Shocker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herman_Schultz_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Herman Schultz (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"): An accomplice of Toomes who is the second person to use modified, vibro-blast shooting versions of [Brock Rumlow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brock_Rumlow_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Brock Rumlow (Marvel Cinematic Universe)")'s gauntlets.[[47]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Woodbine-50)[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-/FilmSetVisitPg2-24)
*   [Tyne Daly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyne_Daly "Tyne Daly") as [Anne Marie Hoag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anne_Marie_Hoag_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Anne Marie Hoag (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"): The head of the [U.S. Department of Damage Control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damage_Control_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Damage Control (Marvel Cinematic Universe)").[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Daly-51)[[49]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-HeavyEasterEggs-52)
*   [Marisa Tomei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marisa_Tomei "Marisa Tomei") as [May Parker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/May_Parker_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "May Parker (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"):

Peter's aunt.[[50]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Tomei-53)[[51]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Zendaya2-54) First reports of Tomei's casting caused backlash on social media, with comic book fans opining that the actress was "too young and attractive to portray the character",[[52]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-TomeiBacklash-55) especially after the character had [previously been depicted by](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aunt_May#Films "Aunt May") actresses older than Tomei. Regarding the casting, _[Captain America: Civil War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Captain\_America:\_Civil\_War "Captain America: Civil War")_ (2016) co-writer [Stephen McFeely](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_Markus_and_Stephen_McFeely "Christopher Markus and Stephen McFeely") said that, for the MCU, they were trying to make Peter "as naturalistic as possible...That's partly why his aunt isn't 80 years old; if she's the sister of his dead mother, why does she have to be two generations ahead?"[[53]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-AuntMayAge-56) Carroll added that the creative team was looking for more of a "big sister" or someone closer in age to Peter Parker in the casting process.[[54]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-VanityFairJuly2017-57) After researching the character, Tomei did make "a case to age me up, but no they didn't do it".[[55]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-TomeiColbert-58) Tomei felt there was a "blank slate" from which she could develop the character, and talked to Watts about May being "a community organizer or invested in the neighborhood" to indicate where Peter's values come from.[[56]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-TomeiVarietyJul2017-59)
*   [Robert Downey Jr.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Downey_Jr. "Robert Downey Jr.") as [Tony Stark / Iron Man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Stark_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Tony Stark (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"):

A self-described genius, billionaire, playboy, philanthropist, and an Avenger with [electromechanical suits of armor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iron_Man%27s_armor_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Iron Man's armor (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") of his own invention who is Parker's mentor and the creator of the U.S. Department of Damage Control.[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-/FilmSetVisitPg2-24)[[57]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Downey-60)[Sony Pictures Motion Picture Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony_Pictures_Motion_Picture_Group "Sony Pictures Motion Picture Group") chairman [Tom Rothman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Rothman "Tom Rothman") noted that, beyond the commercial advantage of featuring Downey in the film, the inclusion of Stark was important due to the relationship established between him and Parker in _Captain America: Civil War_.[[58]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-RothmanDowney-61) Watts noted that after Stark's actions in _Civil War_, introducing Parker to life as an Avenger, there are "a lot of repercussions to that. Is it a first step towards Tony as some sort of mentor figure? Is he comfortable with that?"[[59]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-DamageControl-62) Co-writer [Jonathan Goldstein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonathan_Goldstein_(filmmaker) "Jonathan Goldstein (filmmaker)") compared Stark to [Ethan Hawke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethan_Hawke "Ethan Hawke")'s father character in _[Boyhood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boyhood\_(2014\_film) "Boyhood (2014 film)")_ (2014).[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-GoldsteinDaleyCS-22)

> There are so many things from the comics that haven't been done yet ... stories [that Spider-Man is] in high school for a lot of it. We want to explore that. That also makes him very, very different from any of our other characters in the MCU

Following the [November 2014 hacking of Sony's computers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony_Pictures_hack "Sony Pictures hack"), emails between [Sony Pictures Entertainment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony_Pictures "Sony Pictures") co-chairman [Amy Pascal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amy_Pascal "Amy Pascal") and president [Doug Belgrad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doug_Belgrad "Doug Belgrad") were released, stating that Sony wanted [Marvel Studios](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Studios "Marvel Studios") to produce a new trilogy of Spider-Man films while Sony retained "creative control, marketing, and distribution". Discussions between Sony and Marvel broke down, and Sony planned to proceed with its own [slate of Spider-Man films](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Amazing_Spider-Man_(film_series) "The Amazing Spider-Man (film series)").[[96]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Dec2014WSJ-100) However, in February 2015, Sony Pictures and Marvel Studios announced that they would release a new Spider-Man film, with [Kevin Feige](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_Feige "Kevin Feige") and Pascal producing (the latter through her company [Pascal Pictures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pascal_Pictures "Pascal Pictures")).[[97]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-SpideyMCU-101)[[98]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-PascalPictures-102) The character would first appear in an earlier [Marvel Cinematic Universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe "Marvel Cinematic Universe") (MCU) film,[[97]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-SpideyMCU-101) later revealed to be _[Captain America: Civil War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Captain\_America:\_Civil\_War "Captain America: Civil War")_ (2016).[[99]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-SpideyCivilWar-103) Marvel Studios would explore opportunities to integrate [MCU characters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Characters_of_the_Marvel_Cinematic_Universe "Characters of the Marvel Cinematic Universe") into future Spider-Man films, which Sony Pictures would continue to finance, distribute, and have final creative control over.[[97]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-SpideyMCU-101) Both studios have the ability to terminate the agreement at any point, and no money was exchanged with the deal. However, a small adjustment was made to a 2011 deal that gave Marvel full control of Spider-Man's merchandising rights, in exchange for a one-time payment of $175 million to Sony and paying up to $35 million for each future Spider-Man film rather than receiving their previous five percent of a Spider-Man film's revenue—Marvel could now reduce their $35 million payment if the co-produced film grossed more than $750 million.[[100]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-WSJDealNumbers-104) Marvel Studios still received five percent of first dollar gross for the film.[[101]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FirstDollarGross-105)[Lone Star Funds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lone_Star_Funds "Lone Star Funds") also co-financed the film with Sony, via its [LSC Film Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LStar_Capital "LStar Capital") deal,[[102]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-SonyLSC-106) covering 25 percent of the $175 million budget,[[103]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-DeadlineWknd1-107) while [Columbia Pictures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Columbia_Pictures "Columbia Pictures") officially served as co-producer with Marvel Studios.[[104]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-ColumbiaPictures-108) Sony also paid Marvel Studios an undisclosed producer fee.[[105]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-ProducerFee-109)

Marvel had been working to add Spider-Man to the Marvel Cinematic Universe since at least October 2014, when they announced their slate of [Phase Three](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe:_Phase_Three "Marvel Cinematic Universe: Phase Three") films, with Feige saying, "Marvel doesn't announce anything officially until it's set in stone. So we went forward with that Plan A in October, with the Plan B being, if [the deal] were to happen with Sony, how it would all shift. We've been thinking about [the Spider-Man film] as long as we've been thinking about Phase Three."[[106]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FeigeCraveApril2015-110)[Avi Arad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avi_Arad "Avi Arad") and [Matt Tolmach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Tolmach "Matt Tolmach"), producers for _The Amazing Spider-Man_ series, were set to serve as executive producers,[[107]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-THRFeb2015-111) with neither director [Marc Webb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc_Webb "Marc Webb") nor actor [Andrew Garfield](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Garfield "Andrew Garfield") returning for the new film.[[108]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-WebbGarfield-112) Sony was reportedly looking for an actor younger than Garfield to play Spider-Man,[[107]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-THRFeb2015-111) with [Logan Lerman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logan_Lerman "Logan Lerman") and [Dylan O'Brien](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dylan_O%27Brien "Dylan O'Brien") considered front-runners.[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-LermanO'BrienFrontRunners-113) In March 2015, [Drew Goddard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drew_Goddard "Drew Goddard") was being considered to write and direct the film,[[110]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-GoddardDeadline-114)[[111]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-GoddardTHR-115) while O'Brien said he had not been approached for the role.[[112]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-O'BrienDeny-116) Goddard, who was previously attached to a Sony film based on the [Sinister Six](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinister_Six "Sinister Six"), later said he declined to work on the new film as he thought he "didn't really have an idea" for it and struggled with the idea of working on a new film after spending a year working on the Sinister Six film and being in that mindset.[[113]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-GoddardReason-117) The following month, while promoting _[Avengers: Age of Ultron](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avengers:\_Age\_of\_Ultron "Avengers: Age of Ultron")_ (2015), Feige said the character of [Peter Parker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Parker_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Peter Parker (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") would be around 15 to 16 years old in the film,[[95]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FeigeColliderApril2015-99) which would not be an [origin story](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Origin_story "Origin story"), since "there have been two retellings of that origin in the last [thirteen years, so] we are going to take it for granted that people know that, and the specifics".[[106]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FeigeCraveApril2015-110) Parker's [Uncle Ben](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncle_Ben "Uncle Ben") is still referenced in the film,[[114]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-/FilmSetVisitPg1-118) but not by name.[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-WattsScreenCrush-119) There was some discussion to include a direct reference to Ben when Peter is getting ready for his [homecoming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homecoming "Homecoming") by the revelation that his wardrobe consisted of Ben's clothes, but the writers desisted because they felt that the moment veered away from Parker's [character arc](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Character_arc "Character arc") and made Ben's death feel like a "throwaway line".[[116]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-WritersAnswers-120) Later in April, [Nat Wolff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nat_Wolff "Nat Wolff"), [Asa Butterfield](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asa_Butterfield "Asa Butterfield"), [Tom Holland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Holland "Tom Holland"), [Timothée Chalamet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timoth%C3%A9e_Chalamet "Timothée Chalamet"), and [Liam James](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liam_James "Liam James") were under consideration by Sony and Marvel to play Spider-Man,[[117]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-SpideyActors-121) with Holland and Butterfield as the front-runners.[[118]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-SpideyFinalists-122)[Joseph Quinn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Quinn_(actor) "Joseph Quinn (actor)") and [Chandler Riggs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chandler_Riggs "Chandler Riggs") also auditioned for the role.[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-QuinnAudition-123)[[120]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-RiggsAudition-124)

In May 2015, [Jonathan Levine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonathan_Levine "Jonathan Levine"), [Ted Melfi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ted_Melfi "Ted Melfi"), [Jason Moore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jason_Moore_(director) "Jason Moore (director)"), the writing team of [John Francis Daley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Francis_Daley "John Francis Daley") and [Jonathan Goldstein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonathan_Goldstein_(filmmaker) "Jonathan Goldstein (filmmaker)"), and [Jared Hess](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jared_Hess "Jared Hess") were being considered to direct the film.[[121]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-May2015Directors-125) Butterfield, Holland, [Judah Lewis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judah_Lewis "Judah Lewis"), [Matt Lintz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Lintz "Matt Lintz"), [Charlie Plummer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlie_Plummer "Charlie Plummer"), and [Charlie Rowe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlie_Rowe "Charlie Rowe")[screen-tested](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Screen-test "Screen-test") for the lead role against [Robert Downey Jr.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Downey_Jr. "Robert Downey Jr."), who portrays [Tony Stark / Iron Man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Stark_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Tony Stark (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") in the MCU, for "chemistry".[[122]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-THRCastingSecrets-126)[[123]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-SpideyCastingCall-127) The six were chosen out of a search of over 1,500 actors to test in front of Feige, Pascal, and the [Russo brothers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russo_brothers "Russo brothers")—the directors of _Captain America: Civil War_.[[123]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-SpideyCastingCall-127) Lintz would later be cast as [Bruno Carrelli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruno_Carrelli "Bruno Carrelli") in the Marvel Studios [Disney+](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disney%2B "Disney+") series _[Ms. Marvel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ms.\_Marvel\_(miniseries) "Ms. Marvel (miniseries)")_ (2022).[[124]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-LintzMsMarvel-128) By early June 2015, Levine and Melfi had become the favorites to direct the film, with Daley and Goldstein and [Jon Watts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jon_Watts "Jon Watts") also in consideration,[[125]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-June2015Directors-129) while Feige and Pascal narrowed the actors considered to Holland and Rowe, with both screen-testing with Downey again. Holland also tested with [Chris Evans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Evans_(actor) "Chris Evans (actor)"), who portrays [Steve Rogers / Captain America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Rogers_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Steve Rogers (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") in the MCU and emerged as the favorite.[[122]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-THRCastingSecrets-126) On June 23, Marvel and Sony officially announced that Holland would star as Spider-Man and that Watts would direct the film.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-HollandWatts-13) The Russos "were pretty vocal about who [_[sic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sic "Sic")_] [they] wanted for the part", pushing to cast an actor close to the age of Peter Parker to differentiate from the previous portrayals. They also praised Holland for having a dancing and gymnastics background.[[99]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-SpideyCivilWar-103) Watts was able to read the _Civil War_ script, talk with the Russos, and was on set for the filming of Spider-Man's scenes in that film.[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-WattsScreenCrush-119) He was able to "see what they were doing with it" and provide "ideas about this and that",[[126]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-WattsJun2016-130) including what Parker's bedroom and wardrobe looked like "so that my movie transitions seamlessly with theirs".[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-WattsScreenCrush-119) On joining the MCU and directing the film, Watts said he was excited to explore the "ground level" of the MCU, a world where characters like the Avengers exist but have only been depicted in previous films at "the Penthouse level of the Marvel world".[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-/FilmSetVisitPg2-24)

Before getting the job of director, Watts created images of [Nick Fury](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nick_Fury_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Nick Fury (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") as Parker's mentor in the story in early "mood reels" saying, "I don't know what the situation would be, but that would be a person he'd want to get in trouble with."[[127]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Fury-131) Feige said the films of [John Hughes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Hughes_(filmmaker) "John Hughes (filmmaker)") would be a major influence and that Parker's personal growth and development would be just as important as his role as Spider-Man. He noted that "at that age, in high school, everything feels like life or death". He also said that the film hoped to use one of [Spider-Man's rogues](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Spider-Man_enemies "List of Spider-Man enemies") that have not [been seen in film yet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Spider-Man_enemies_in_other_media#Film "List of Spider-Man enemies in other media"),[[128]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FeigeJune2015-132) and that filming would begin in June 2016.[[129]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Filming-133) In July 2015, it was reported that [Marisa Tomei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marisa_Tomei "Marisa Tomei") had been offered the role of [May Parker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/May_Parker_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "May Parker (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"), Peter's aunt.[[50]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Tomei-53) It was also revealed that Daley and Goldstein, after missing out on the director role, had begun negotiations to write the screenplay,[[130]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-DaleyGoldsteinScreenplay-134) and were given three days to present Marvel with their [pitch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pitch_(filmmaking) "Pitch (filmmaking)");[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-DaleyGoldsteinTHR-135) both confirmed shortly after that they had reached a deal to write the screenplay.[[132]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-DaleyGoldsteinConfirm-136) The pair had proposed a take on the character that was "diametrically opposed" to the previous Spider-Man films, creating a [laundry list](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/laundry_list "wikt:laundry list") of all the elements seen in those films and actively trying to avoid re-using them. They chose to focus on the high school aspects of the character rather than the "drama and weight of the tragedy that leads to the origin of Spider-Man". They felt this would differentiate him from the other MCU superheroes as well.[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-GoldsteinDaleyCS-22) Daley said the film was about Parker "finding his place" in the MCU, with the writing team wanting the film to focus on him "coming to terms with his new abilities and not yet being good with them, and carrying with him some real human fears and weaknesses", such as a fear of heights when he has to scale the [Washington Monument](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Monument "Washington Monument"). Daley noted, "Even within the context of this movie, I don't think you would feel that fear of heights or even the vertigo the audience feels in that scene if you establish him as swinging from skyscrapers at the top of the movie."[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-DaleyGoldsteinTHR2-20) The writers also wanted to avoid the skyscrapers of [Manhattan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan") because of how often they were used in the other films, and instead wrote the character into locations such as "the suburbs, on a golf course, the [Staten Island Ferry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Staten_Island_Ferry "Staten Island Ferry"), [Coney Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coney_Island "Coney Island"), and even Washington, D.C." One of the first sequences they pitched was "seeing Spider-Man attached to a plane 10,000 feet up in the air, where he had absolutely no safety net. ... you're familiar with the sort of areas he's been in, [so] why not turn it on its head and make it something different that people haven't seen before?"[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-GoldsteinDaleyCS-22) The pair conceded that the film took a more grounded, "low-stakes" approach than previous films, which avoided having to explain why the Avengers were not helping, since a world-threatening problem would logically require the "big guys".[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-DaleyGoldsteinTHR2-20)

Marvel encouraged Daley and Goldstein to express their own sense of humor in the script, with Daley saying, "When you're seeing the world through the eyes of a fun, funny kid, you can really embrace that voice, and not give him the cookie-cutter one-liners that you're so accustomed to hearing from Peter Parker." Inspired by their experiences working on [sitcoms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sitcom "Sitcom"), the writers also looked to create "a network of strong characters" to surround Parker with in the film.[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-GoldsteinDaleyCS-22) In October 2015, Watts said he was looking to make the film a [coming-of-age story](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coming-of-age_story "Coming-of-age story") to see the growth of Parker, citing _[Can't Buy Me Love](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Can%27t\_Buy\_Me\_Love\_(film) "Can't Buy Me Love (film)")_ (1987), _[Say Anything...](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Say\_Anything... "Say Anything...")_ (1989), and _[Almost Famous](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Almost\_Famous "Almost Famous")_ (2000) as some of his favorite films in that genre.[[133]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-WattsOct2015-137) It was this aspect of the film that had initially got Watts interested in directing it, as he had already been looking to make a coming-of-age story when he heard that the new Spider-Man would be younger than previous incarnations.[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-WattsJun2017-138) Watts re-read the original Spider-Man comics in preparation for the film, and "came to a new realization" about the character's original popularity, feeling that he introduced a new perspective to the comics that had already established "a crazy spectacular Marvel Universe ... to give a regular person's perspective on it". He felt that this was also the responsibility of this film since it had to introduce Spider-Man to the already established MCU.[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-WattsScreenCrush-119) Specific comics that Watts noted as potential influences were _[Ultimate Spider-Man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultimate\_Spider-Man "Ultimate Spider-Man")_ (2000-2011) and _[Spider-Man Loves Mary Jane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man\_Loves\_Mary\_Jane "Spider-Man Loves Mary Jane")_ (2004-2009).[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-WattsJun2017-138) In December, Oliver Scholl signed on to be the production designer for the film.[[135]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Scholl-139)

[![Image 3](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Jon_Watts_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg/250px-Jon_Watts_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Jon_Watts_by_Gage_Skidmore_2.jpg)

Watts promoting _Spider-Man: Homecoming_ at the 2016 San Diego Comic-Con

Watts wanted to heavily pre-visualize the film, especially its action sequences, as he does on all his films. For _Homecoming_, Watts worked with a team to "figure out the visual language for the action sequences and ... try stuff out before" filming began to help Watts practice given his lack of experience working on large-scale films. For the "web-slinging" sequences, Watts wanted to avoid the big "swoopy" camera moves that had been previously used and instead "keep it all as grounded as possible. So, whether it was shooting with a drone camera or a helicopter or a cable-cam, or even just handheld, up on a roof chasing after him, I wanted it to feel like we were there with him."[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-WattsJun2017-138)

In January 2016, Sony shifted the film's release date from July 28, 2017, to July 7, 2017,[[136]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-NewReleaseDate-140) and said the film would be digitally remastered for [IMAX 3D](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IMAX_3D "IMAX 3D") in post-production.[[137]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-IMAX3D-141)[J. K. Simmons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._K._Simmons "J. K. Simmons") expressed interest in reprising his role as [J. Jonah Jameson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Jonah_Jameson_(film_character) "J. Jonah Jameson (film character)") from [Sam Raimi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Raimi "Sam Raimi")'s [_Spider-Man_ films](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man_(2002_film_series) "Spider-Man (2002 film series)").[[138]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-SimmonsInterest-142) In early March, [Zendaya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zendaya "Zendaya") was cast in the film as Michelle, and Tomei was confirmed as May Parker.[[51]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Zendaya2-54)[[139]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Zendaya-143) The following month, Feige confirmed that characters from previous MCU films would appear,[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FeigeApr2016-144) and clarified that the deal formed with Sony does not specify which characters can and cannot crossover.[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FeigeApr2016Collider-145) He noted that the sharing between the studios was done with "good faith" in order "to have more toys to play with as we put together a story",[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-CharacterGF-9) and that "the agreement was that it is very much a Sony Pictures movie... we are the creative producers. We are the ones hiring the actor, introducing him in [_Civil War_], and then working right now on the script and soon to be shooting."[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FeigeApr2016Collider-145) Sony Pictures chairman Tom Rothman further added that Sony has final greenlight authority, but were deferring creatively to Marvel.[[142]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-RothmanJune2016-146) At [CinemaCon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CinemaCon "CinemaCon") 2016, Sony announced the title of the film to be _Spider-Man: Homecoming_,[[143]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-VarietyTitle-147)[[144]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Homecoming-148) a reference to the common high school tradition homecoming as well as the character "coming home" to Marvel and the MCU.[[144]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Homecoming-148)[Tony Revolori](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Revolori "Tony Revolori") – who had auditioned for Peter Parker[[145]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-RevoloriAudition-149) – and [Laura Harrier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laura_Harrier "Laura Harrier") joined the cast as classmates of Parker's,[[42]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Harrier2-45)[[146]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Harrier-150) and Downey Jr. was revealed to be in the film as Stark.[[57]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Downey-60)[[147]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-DowneyConfirmed-151) Watts noted that Stark "was always a part of" the film's story because of his interactions with Parker in _Civil War_.[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-WattsJun2017-138) Downey Jr. was paid $10 million for his involvement.[[148]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-DowneySalary-152)

Also in April, [Michael Keaton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Keaton "Michael Keaton") entered talks to play a villain,[[149]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Keaton-153) but dropped out of discussions shortly thereafter due to scheduling conflicts with the film _[The Founder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Founder "The Founder")_ (2016).[[150]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Keaton2-154)[[151]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-KeatonNerdist-155) At this point, [John Leguizamo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Leguizamo "John Leguizamo") was approached to fill the role and entered negotiations to do so.[[152]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-LeguizamoVulture-156) Keaton soon reentered talks for the role after a change in schedule for _The Founder_,[[151]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-KeatonNerdist-155)[[153]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Keaton3-157) which necessitated Marvel to ask Leguizamo if he would step away from the role in order to cast Keaton;[[152]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-LeguizamoVulture-156) Keaton closed the deal in late May.[[153]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Keaton3-157) Marvel offered to cast Leguizamo in another role, which he considered "tiny" and declined.[[152]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-LeguizamoVulture-156)[Mark Hamill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Hamill "Mark Hamill") was interested in playing the film's villain in case Keaton turned down the offer, but Keaton reconsidered the offer in time.[[154]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-MarkHamillVulture-158) In June, [Michael Barbieri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Barbieri_(actor) "Michael Barbieri (actor)") was cast as a friend of Parker's,[[88]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Barbieri-92)[[89]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-BarbieriConfirm-93)[Kenneth Choi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_Choi "Kenneth Choi") was cast as Parker's high school principal,[[70]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Choi-73) and [Logan Marshall-Green](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logan_Marshall-Green "Logan Marshall-Green") was cast as another villain alongside Keaton's character,[[65]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-MarshallGreen-68)[[68]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Mando-71) while [Donald Glover](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Glover "Donald Glover") and [Martin Starr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Starr "Martin Starr") joined the cast in undisclosed roles.[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Glover-36)[[75]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Starr-78) Watts said that he wanted the cast to reflect Queens as "one of [the] most diverse places in the world",[[126]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-WattsJun2016-130) with Feige adding that "we want everyone to recognize themselves in every portion of our universe. [With this cast] especially, it really feels like this is absolutely what has to happen and continue."[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-USATodaySDCC2016-46) This is also different from the previous films, which were "set in a lily-white Queens high school".[[155]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FeigeDiversity-159) Additionally, Marvel made a conscious decision to mostly avoid including or referencing characters who appeared in previous _Spider-Man_ films, outside of major ones like Peter and May Parker, and [Flash Thompson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flash_Thompson "Flash Thompson"). This included the _[Daily Bugle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daily\_Bugle "Daily Bugle")_, with co-producer [Eric Hauserman Carroll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eric_Hauserman_Carroll "Eric Hauserman Carroll") saying, "We toyed with it for a while, but again, we didn't want to go down that road right away, and if we do do a _Daily Bugle_, we want to do it in a way that feels contemporary".[[114]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-/FilmSetVisitPg1-118) This also included the character [Mary Jane Watson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_Jane_Watson "Mary Jane Watson"), but Zendaya's Michelle was eventually given the initials "MJ" as a nod to that character. Feige said that the point of this is "to have fun with [references] while at the same time having it be different characters that can provide a different dynamic".[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FeigeDenOfGeek-33)

Spider-Man's costume in the film has more technical improvements than the previous suits, including the logo on the chest being a remote drone, an [AI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence "Artificial intelligence") system similar to Stark's [J.A.R.V.I.S.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edwin_Jarvis#J.A.R.V.I.S. "Edwin Jarvis"), a holographic interface, a parachute, a tracking device for Stark to track Parker, a heater, an airbag, the ability to light up, and the ability to augment reality with the eyepieces. Stark also builds in a "training wheels" protocol, to initially limit Parker's access to all of its features. Carroll noted Marvel went through the comics and "pull[ed] out all the sort of fun and wacky things the suit did" to include in the _Homecoming_ suit.[[156]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-IGNSpideySuit-160) Spider-Man's web-shooters have various settings, first teased at the end of _Civil War_, which Carroll explained allowed him to "adjust the spray" to different settings like the spinning web, web ball, or ricochet web. He compared this to a [DSLR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_single-lens_reflex_camera "Digital single-lens reflex camera") camera.[[114]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-/FilmSetVisitPg1-118)

[Principal photography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principal_photography "Principal photography") began on June 20, 2016,[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FilmingStart-161) at [Pinewood Atlanta Studios](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinewood_Atlanta_Studios "Pinewood Atlanta Studios") in [Fayette County, Georgia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fayette_County,_Georgia "Fayette County, Georgia"),[[158]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Pinewood-162) under the [working title](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Working_title "Working title")_Summer of George_.[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-WorkingTitle-163)[Salvatore Totino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salvatore_Totino "Salvatore Totino") served as director of photography.[[160]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-SalvatoreTotino-164) Filming also took place in [Atlanta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta"), with locations including [Grady High School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_W._Grady_High_School "Henry W. Grady High School"),[[161]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Grady-165)[Downtown Atlanta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downtown_Atlanta "Downtown Atlanta"),[[162]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Downtown-166) the [Atlanta Marriott Marquis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlanta_Marriott_Marquis "Atlanta Marriott Marquis"),[[163]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-MarriottMarquis-167)[Piedmont Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piedmont_Park "Piedmont Park"), the [Georgia World Congress Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgia_World_Congress_Center "Georgia World Congress Center"),[[164]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-AJCJuly2017-168) and the [West End](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_End,_Atlanta "West End, Atlanta") neighborhood.[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-/FilmSetVisitPg3-169) Holland said building New York sets in Atlanta was cheaper than actually filming in New York, a location closely associated with the character, though the production may "end up [in New York] for one week or two".[[166]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-HollandSuperHeroHype-170) A replica of the Staten Island Ferry was built in Atlanta, with the ability to open and close in half in 10 to 12 seconds and be flooded with 40,000 gallons of water in 8 seconds.[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FXGuide-171) Additional filming also occurred at two [magnet schools](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnet_schools "Magnet schools") in the [Van Nuys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van_Nuys "Van Nuys") and [Reseda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reseda,_Los_Angeles "Reseda, Los Angeles") neighborhoods of Los Angeles.[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-LASchools-172)

Casting continued after the start of production, with the inclusion of [Isabella Amara](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isabella_Amara "Isabella Amara"), [Jorge Lendeborg Jr.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jorge_Lendeborg_Jr. "Jorge Lendeborg Jr."), [Josie Totah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josie_Totah "Josie Totah"),[[80]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Trio-83)[Hannibal Buress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hannibal_Buress "Hannibal Buress"),[[72]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Buress-75)[Selenis Leyva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selenis_Leyva "Selenis Leyva"),[[77]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Leyva-80)[Abraham Attah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abraham_Attah "Abraham Attah"),[[84]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Attah-88)[Michael Mando](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Mando "Michael Mando"),[[68]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Mando-71)[Tyne Daly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyne_Daly "Tyne Daly"),[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Daly-51)[Garcelle Beauvais](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garcelle_Beauvais "Garcelle Beauvais"), [Tiffany Espensen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiffany_Espensen "Tiffany Espensen"),[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-BeauvaisEspensen-65) and [Angourie Rice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angourie_Rice "Angourie Rice") in unspecified roles,[[86]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Rice-90) with [Bokeem Woodbine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bokeem_Woodbine "Bokeem Woodbine") joining as an additional villain.[[47]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Woodbine-50) At [San Diego Comic-Con](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Diego_Comic-Con "San Diego Comic-Con") in 2016, Marvel confirmed the castings of Keaton, Zendaya, Glover, Harrier, Revolori, Daly, and Woodbine, while revealing Zendaya, Harrier, and Revolori's roles as Michelle, [Liz Allan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liz_Allan "Liz Allan"), and [Flash Thompson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flash_Thompson_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Flash Thompson (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"), respectively,[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-EWCastnames-29)[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-SDCC2016-39)[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-USATodaySDCC2016-46)[[169]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-NewsaramaCast-173) and announcing the casting of [Jacob Batalon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_Batalon "Jacob Batalon") as Ned.[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-SDCC2016-39)[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-IGNNedLeeds-40)[Lewis Pullman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lewis_Pullman "Lewis Pullman") also auditioned for Ned.[[170]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Pullman-174) It was also revealed that the [Adrian Toomes / Vulture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adrian_Toomes_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Adrian Toomes (Marvel Cinematic Universe)") would be the film's villain, while the writing teams of Watts and [Christopher Ford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_Ford_(screenwriter) "Christopher Ford (screenwriter)"), and [Chris McKenna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_McKenna_(writer) "Chris McKenna (writer)") and [Erik Sommers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erik_Sommers "Erik Sommers"), joined Goldstein and Daley in writing the screenplay,[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-SDCC2016-39) from Goldstein and Daley's story. Eric Pearson, a member of Marvel Studios' writing program who had written the [Marvel One-Shot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_One-Shot "Marvel One-Shot") films, did uncredited work on the film as well.[[171]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Pearson-175) Watts praised Goldstein and Daley's drafts as "really fun and funny", and said that they "sort of established the broad strokes of the movie", with him and Ford, close friends since childhood, then re-writing the script based on specific ideas that Watts had and things that he wanted to film, which he said was a "pretty substantial structural pass, rearranging things and building it into the sort of story arc we wanted it to be". McKenna and Sommers then joined the film to deal with changes to the script during filming, as "it's all a little bit flexible when you get to set. You try things out, and you just need someone to be writing while you're shooting."[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-WattsJun2017-138)

Harrier noted that the young actors in the film "constantly refer to ourselves as _The Breakfast Club_".[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-EWCastnames-29) Shortly after, [Martha Kelly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martha_Kelly "Martha Kelly") joined the cast in an unspecified role.[[90]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Kelly-94) In August, [Michael Chernus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Chernus "Michael Chernus") was cast as [Phineas Mason / Tinkerer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phineas_Mason_(Marvel_Cinematic_Universe) "Phineas Mason (Marvel Cinematic Universe)"),[[67]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Chernus-70) while [Jona Xiao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jona_Xiao "Jona Xiao") joined the cast in an unspecified role,[[172]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Xiao-176) and Buress said he was playing a gym teacher.[[73]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Buress2-76) By September 2016, [Jon Favreau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jon_Favreau "Jon Favreau") was reprising his role as [Happy Hogan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Happy_Hogan_(comics) "Happy Hogan (comics)") from the _Iron Man_ series,[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Favreau-25) and filming concluded in Atlanta and moved to New York City. Locations in the latter city included [Astoria, Queens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astoria,_Queens "Astoria, Queens"); [Sunnyside, Queens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunnyside,_Queens "Sunnyside, Queens"); [St. George, Staten Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._George,_Staten_Island "St. George, Staten Island"); [Manhattan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan");[[173]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-NewYorkFilming-177)[[174]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-NewYorkFilming2-178)[[175]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-NewYorkFilming3-179)[[176]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-NewYorkFilming4-180) and [Franklin K. Lane High School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franklin_K._Lane_High_School "Franklin K. Lane High School") in [Brooklyn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brooklyn "Brooklyn").[[114]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-/FilmSetVisitPg1-118) Additionally, [UFC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultimate_Fighting_Championship "Ultimate Fighting Championship") fighter [Tyron Woodley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyron_Woodley "Tyron Woodley") said he had been considered for a villain role in the film, but had to drop out due to a prior commitment with [Fox Sports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Sports_(United_States) "Fox Sports (United States)").[[177]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Woodley-181) Principal photography [wrapped](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wrap_(filmmaking) "Wrap (filmmaking)") on October 2, 2016, in New York City,[[178]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-FilmingWrap-182) with some additional filming taking place later in the month in Berlin, Germany, near the [Brandenburg Gate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brandenburg_Gate "Brandenburg Gate").[[179]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spider-Man:_Homecoming#cite_note-Berlin-183)
